title: 107_hr3041
content: The Act may be cited as the "Travel America Now Act of 2001". Prior to September 11, 2001, the travel and tourism industry in the United States employed over 19 million people with a payroll of $171.5 billion. In 2000, the industry generated over $582 billion in expenditures and $99.6 billion in tax revenues. Additionally, it created a $14 billion trade surplus for the country. Post-9/11, efforts are being made to ensure the safety and security of travel. Increased consumer spending on travel and tourism is crucial for revitalizing the US economy post-9/11. The public should be encouraged to travel for both personal and business reasons to support working people and stimulate cash flow. SEC. 25C. PERSONAL TRAVEL CREDIT is a new section added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, encouraging personal travel by providing a credit for travel expenses. The new section added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, SEC. 25C, allows individuals a tax credit for qualified personal travel expenses incurred between the enactment date and January 1, 2002. The maximum credit is $500 for individuals and $1,000 for joint returns, covering expenses related to travel and lodging. The term 'qualifying personal trip' refers to travel within the United States that includes an overnight stay at a commercial lodging facility located at least 100 miles away from the taxpayer's residence, and taken after the enactment of this section. The term 'commercial lodging facility' includes hotels, motels, resorts, rooming houses, or campgrounds. Special rules deny the credit if a deduction is allowable to another taxpayer for the same individual. Expenses must be substantiated for the credit to be allowed. The text discusses the denial of double benefits for expenses claimed under the Internal Revenue Code, requiring adequate records or evidence to support expense deductions. The term 'commercial lodging facility' is defined, and special rules apply to prevent multiple deductions for the same individual. Sec. 25C. Personal travel credit. The amendments apply to taxable years ending after the enactment date. TEMPORARY INCREASE IN DEDUCTION FOR BUSINESS MEALS AND ENTERTAINMENT. Subsection (n) of section 274 is amended to allow 100 percent deduction for expenses incurred before January 1, 2002. Effective date is for taxable years ending after the enactment date. SEC. 5. Net operating loss carryback for travel and tourism industry. The amendment allows travel and tourism industry losses to be carried back for 5 years preceding the loss year. The amendment allows travel and tourism industry losses to be carried back for 5 years preceding the loss year. Rules relating to travel and tourism industry losses define the term 'travel or tourism loss' as the lesser of the net operating loss for the taxable year from travel or tourism businesses or the overall net operating loss for that year. The term 'travel or tourism business' includes activities directly related to travel or tourism, such as commercial transportation services. The provision of commercial transportation, lodging, operation of airports, travel agent services, convention facilities, and other specified services are eligible for travel and tourism industry losses to be carried back for 5 years. Coordination with specified liability losses is required, and taxpayers have the option to make an election. Taxpayers in the travel and tourism industry can elect to carry back losses for 5 years without certain restrictions. Additionally, related taxpayers can credit travel or tourism losses against taxable income earned during the carryback period. The amendments allow taxpayers in the travel and tourism industry to carry back losses for 5 years without restrictions. Related taxpayers can credit these losses against taxable income earned during the carryback period. Effective date applies to taxable years before, on, or after the enactment of the Act. The Act is based on Congress's power to levy taxes as outlined in article I, section 8 of the US Constitution.
